>>15111645
a) [(n-1)(n-2)..(n-k+1)]^-1 * [(n-k)!]^-1
b) P = sum_k P(cycle containing 1 has length k) * (1 - [(n-1)*...*(n-k+1)]^-1)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15111645
Easy to do with straightforward counting arguments :

number of cycles containing 1 of length k:
(n - 1) ... (n - k + 1)
number of permutations of length (n-k) :
(n-k)!
thus number of permutations with a cycle of length k containing 1:
(n-k)! * (n-1) ... (n-k+1) = (n-1)!
number of total permutations:
n!
probability of getting cycle containing 1 to be of length k:
(n-1)!/n! = 1/n
Suppose 1 is in a cycle of length k. This cycle will contain k-1 other elements, there are (n-1) choose (k-1) ways to choose these elements (neglecting order, but this is fine). If we insist 2 is one of these elements, there become only (n-2) choose (k-2) ways. Hence the probability of this cycle containing k is :
[(n-2) choose (k-2)] / [(n-1) choose (k-1)] = (k-1) / (n-1).
Taking an average over k gives probability : n(n-1)/2n(n-1) = 1/2.

on f which is constructed from 'duck' with degree 2, this will return true because the distance is 1
f('uck) is true, two deletions
f('cluck') is true, one insertion and one substitution

"States are named using a ne style notation, where n is the number of characters consumed so far, and e is the number of errors.

>>15120555
Here is the actual reason why:
In ancient Mesopotamia, a base 60 number system was used. Some historians believe that they used such a high base because Mesopotamian society was made up of people who used base 5 and base 12. Since the least common multiple of 5 and 12 is 60, these two types of people could only communicate math to one another in base 60.
Mesopotamia was the first society to use 60-second minutes and 60-minute hours. This is also supposedly why the clock is separated into 12’s and 5’s.
No joke, this is actually the reason why. Base 5 was chosen for one group because of 5 fingers to one hand. Base 12 was chosen for the other because you can count up to 12 on one hand by counting the joints on your fingers with your thumb.
I remember reading about this in Mario Livio’s The Golden Ratio over 10 years ago, so I could have some details wrong. Very cute book if you like math, and I highly recommend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15122071
Author-anon, you need a section about licensure as an engineer in the US.

-First Step

Set up your NCEES account.

https://ncees.org/

-Second Step

Take the goddamn FE exam, its best to take this right in your junior or senior year because its basically a comprehensive exam focusing on everything you've learned in undergrad, its an 8 hour marathon so come prepared. The key to passing is knowing how to CTRL-F through the digital handbook they give you. You can buy a hard copy of this handbook for study ahead of time

-Step 3

If you passed the FE easy, then IMMEDIATELY take the PE in your chosen discipline, its quite literally easier than the FE because its not as broad and only focuses on a specific topic. If the FE was hard for you, you might need to study more.

-Step 4

Get a job where you are working underneath another PE. This is the hardest part and it fucking sucks because you will likely be brought on at a lower salary and rode hard for long hours at a design firm (engineering sweatshop). You will also need to make friends with other PE's wherever you work so they will vouch for you. Minimum of three vouches and one "master" who will vouch for 4 years of XP as his apprentice.

-Step 5

Apply for licensure. Once you have the experiential requirements and the tests knocked out, you apply for licensure through NCEES to whatever state you are in. The license requirements do vary by state but there is reciprocity.

>Why the fuck should i do all this

Because those letters next to your name alone are worth a %20 salary increase. Stamping engineers are hard to come by, even harder to recruit once they've found a home. If you want to avoid doing businessman type things and stay on the technical side without bottle necking your career, then getting your license is your best bet

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15122146
i only took the GRE general, so i can help with that.
>quantitative section
if you arent a braindead faggot, you should easily get 90% after going over the math problems for a week or probably less. they all follow the same format and are middle school or early highschool in difficulty. the easiest part to screw up on are misreading the graphs or the problems, but just take your time you have plenty of it for this section.
>verbal reasoning
harder due to the fact there's a huge list of vocabulary they want you to remember. it's been about 3years since i've taken it, but about one third to half of the questions in this section rely on knowing various vocabulary from the list. it can be a simple 'what is the definition of this word,' or 'what is a synonym for this word,' or a 'this is to that as this is to ???', or you may just stumble across it as part of the longer text readings, or many other formats. i went over the vocabulary list for a few hours a day for a couple weeks and got a nice score.
>analytical writing
the topics can range from easy to ballbreakingly tough and hard to decipher. if you look at a few different answers to the types of essays, you'll know how to easily format it, but the problem comes in trying to make arguments or form ideas for some of the most retarded topics that seem to come out of a random topic generator. i almost failed this section because i spent 80% of my time sitting in the chair, sweating my balls off, having no idea what to write. luckily, i had a revelation in the last 10 minutes, and i have decent typing speed, so it saved my ass and was my highest score out of every section somehow.

i cant remember exactly, but i think there are 2 essays at the very beginning, and then alternates between 2-3 sections of verbal reasoning and math with 1 verbal or quantitative section randomly being dropped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15123118
It is a long test, and be sure to count how many sections there are as I thought I was done, but still had 1 last section left and nearly lost all my energy. I used the Cracking GRE books, GRE for dummies, and a bit of the GRE Masterword list though I can't remember which was more helpful between the Cracking GRE and GRE for dummies book. If you dedicate one month for the GRE general, you'll get a fine score. If you dedicate two months, you'll probably get 90% guaranteed as long as you don't shit yourself during the test and get kicked out.

There is a formula for the matrix that projects a vector onto a subspace. If your subspace is spanned by a set of vectors, you use those as the columns of a matrix A, and then [math]A(A^TA}^{-1}A^T[/math] (I forgot a T the first time) is your projection matrix

it's still a bit of a pain in the ass to do by hand, but I think it's reasonable to expect students to do on an exam. I'm pretty sure I had to

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15089929
you need to sample at a rate of at least [math]2f[/math] to faithfully (kinda) capture a signal, where [math]f[/math] is the highest frequency contained in the signal. to capture a 1kHz sine wave, you need to sample at at least 2kHz. a square wave has infinitely high frequency components, so you can technically never truly capture a square wave, you can only be more and more reasonably certain its a square wave the higher you sample.
technically, you can never actually represent a continuous signal with discrete sampling. lets say you sample the peaks and troughs of a 1kHz sine wave (so youd be sampling at 2kHz). you could conclude that the signal is a 1kHz sine wave, but a sine wave of 2.5kHz would produce the exact same samples. these are called aliases, and the higher you sample, the farther out the aliases are; if you sample the 1kHz sine wave at 10kHz, the nearest alias is at 100kHz, i think. if youve ever seen video footage of something spinning really fast and noticed that the video made it look like it was spinning slowly, thats an example of aliasing.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliasing
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyquist_frequency
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyquist%E2%80%93Shannon_sampling_theorem

[math]\begin{align}
x(t) = Ae^{i \omega t} + B^{-i \omega t} &= A(\cos{\omega t} + i\sin{\omega t}) + B(\cos{\omega t} - i\sin{\omega t}) \\
&= (A+B)\cos{\omega t} + (A - B) i\sin{\omega t}
\end{align}[/math]

Then if [math]A = a + ib[/math], and you assume that [math]A = B^*[/math] then [math]A+ A^* = 2a[/math] and [math]A - A^* = 2ib[/math]. So you obtain:

[math]\begin{align}
x(t) &= (A+B)\cos{\omega t} + (A - B) i\sin{\omega t} \\
&= (A+A^*)\cos{\omega t} + (A-A^*) i\sin{\omega t} \\
&= 2a \cos{\omega t} - 2b \sin{\omega t} \\
&= C \cos{\omega t} + D \sin{\omega t}
\end{align}[/math]

where C and D are real and hence so is [math]x(t)[/math].

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15115328
>If I combine both variables (by adding them together) do I end up with a normal distribution?
No. The PDF is either a trapezoid or (if both intervals have the same width) a triangle. The set of possible pairs forms a rectangle in the plane; the probability density is uniform across the rectangle. The set of pairs whose sum is a given value forms a diagonal line. The probability density of the sum is proportional to the length of the line segment obtained by intersecting the line with the rectangle.

For three variables, the probability density is the area of the intersection of a plane with a cuboid, so it has up to 8 points (7 intervals) rather than 4 points (3 intervals) and will look a bit more like a bell curve. The first and last intervals will be quadratic rather than linear. A normal distribution arises from the sum of an infinite number of uniformly-distributed variables.

posts.com: anons, water(liquid) changes to water(gas) at 100°C, so how the fuck are clouds formed cause I don't see any oceans or rivers boiling?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117290
Evaporation, which is not the same thing as boiling.
If you leave water out for some time, some of the molecules on the surface will slowly absorb enough heat from its surroundings to become a gas, gradually reducing the amount of water you have sitting around.
Boiling, in contrast, is directly applying the heat to the water, forcing it all to start evaporating, making it substantially faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117295
so anon, why does boiling water start changing into steam at 100°C, why isn't this achieved at let's say 40-50°C?

or is it that the water starts to change it state at 40°C or so and the temp of 100°C is required to completely change let's say 1L of liquid water into steam?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117369
Pressure.
Every liquid has an associated vapour pressure: it boils when this pressure is equal to that of the atmosphere "trying to keep it in place", so to speak, which is at 100 degrees Celsius for water. Water can evaporate at virtually any temperature so long as it isn't frozen, but it only boils when it's hot enough that it all can counteract the pressure of the atmosphere. That's also why boiling points go down the higher you go from sea level.

You want the greatest variety of prime factors to maximize the number of combinations. You also want the smallest-sized primes. 2*3*5*7*11=2310 is greater than 1000, but 2*3*5*7=210 is not. You have room for an additional *3, or an additional *2*2. The latter results in more combinations (32 factors).

As the largest prime factor (7) may be replaced by multiple smaller factors, it's worth trying numbers whose factors only include multiples of 2, 3, and 5. However, the increased numbers of twos and threes don't match the drastic increase from introducing a seven.

I think I only said "smallest" since, when using shorthand notation, say [math]\operatorname{type}(\mathbb{N})[/math], you're usually not thinking of the relation that well-orders it to be [math]\{2,3,4,...,1\}[/math], which would imply [math]\operatorname{type}(\mathbb{N})=\omega +1[/math], but rather the usual one, for which it's just [math]\omega[/math].

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15118976
if k=2n:
[math]\cos((\pi-2)k)=\cos(\pi{2n}-2(k))=\cos{2n\pi-2k}=\cos{2k}[/math]
if k=2n+1:
[math]\cos((\pi-2)k)=\cos(\pi{2n+1}-2k)=\cos{2n\pi+\pi-k}=\cos{\pi-2k}=-\cos{2k}[/math]

>>15120736
Your first part is wrong because you only consider the first roll. You are suppose to have AT LEAST ONE success in two rolls. So find a way to count all the ways you can have 5 or 6 in at least one of the two rolls, and divide it by the the number of possibility in 2 rolls.

One thing that makes classical probability questions easier is to reduce the problems into of tuples. For this problem, you can use a 2-tuple that represents the represents the result in the first and second roll respectively. So the number of elements in the sample space is 6 times 6 since there are 6 possibilities for the first place, and GIVEN any of those possibilities for the first place, there are additional 6 for the latter. You made the mistake of only counting the possibilities for one position. There are two possibilities for only one position, yes, but now you also have to consider the possibilities for the other position.

Sometimes you cannot multiply and you have to decompose them in to mutually exclusive tuples. Remember that you can add up the possibilities of mutually exclusive tuples. Now think how you can count tuples for your questions. Remember to consider ALL possibilities that pertain to the condition of your question.

For question 2, think how doubles successes can happen and how triple success can happen, and decompose them into mutually exclusive tuples.

Hint first part:
There are three ways the Arne can win:
1. He gets success in the first, but not the second.
2. Other way around.
3. Success in both.
Note these three ways are mutually exclusive, so count for each way and add them up. There is actually faster way to do this which doesn't require counting three way separately. Can you think of one?

Hint second part:
Getting exactly double successes is mutually exclusive to getting triple successes. So addition is valid.

posts.com:
>>15121382
>The assumption that you have a black box in which standing waves of light could exist is extremely idealistic
Any wave with boundary conditions will result in standing waves. The electric field at the walls of any container, be it a box, sphere or whatever, has to be zero which forces you to have to use such boundary conditions in any model.

> the notion that the energy would be distributed among the frequencies according to the equipartition theorem by modelling them as harmonic oscillators doesn't make any sense
The assumption (back then) was that the equipartition theorem was valid for all classical systems so it seemed logical to apply it to such a model even if it was first derived for particles and not waves. There was nothing about harmonic oscillators in the original black body calculations, just the assumption that the equipartition theorem was valid and hence a Boltzmann Distribution of energies should be used. But you are right that this turns out to be a problem and is the fundamental cause of the "ultraviolet catastrophe".

> is there more to the classical theory than I'm giving it credit for?
Yes. The original classical calculations turned out to be correct apart from the function for the distribution. All Plank had to do was with his guess of quantized energy was to then calculate the new distribution function it would generate and then put it into the original calculations. When he did that he ended up with an equation that matched experiments.

Good Afternoon /Sci/entists!

I am a Computer Scientist. I study Computational Maidposting. Last time I posted my research here it was Wolfy MaidSearch and I got all boards banned for three days and my post got jannied off Warosu. I think this happened because a zoomer janny didn't know what a REPL is.

Today I have a useful application of Computational Maidposting in a new Computer Experiment called Kurumi MaidCard. Kurumi MaidCard is a Computer Program which can store compressed text in a Maid Address, and read that text back out of the Maid Address. I named it after Kurumi the vampire maid from Touhou because she came in my threads and helped me with math a lot of times and told me books. Thank you Kurumi, for telling me math ideas.

To get Kurumi MaidCard you need Java 18. Then you need to save MiniMaid.java (case sensitive).

>Get MiniMaid
https://pastebin.com/6ChEa6xS

>Get Kurumi MaidCard
Save the attached image in the same directory you put MiniMaid in, then open a terminal and type

java MiniMaid.java file.png

with "file.png" replaced with whatever you saved the Maid Card as. MiniMaid will extract the full version of Kurumi MaidCard, along with the README, assuming that 4Chan doesn't mess with the pixels of images uploaded to it. The README explains Maid-LZW and how to use the Kurumi MaidCard REPL to make your own Maid Cards.

I plan to use Kurumi MaidCard to distribute all my Computer Experiments. The next one will be the Ilulu Number Calculator/SLAM. This should break my dependence on Pastebin, and let me distribute multi-file Computer Programs so the architecture can be saner and nicer without using GitHub. If you like Computational Maidposting and want to help, please post maids and tell me about ideas from Grzegorczyk Hierarchy.

>tl;dr:
This is what Computer Scientists look like.
Tell the maids.
Especially the maids from Touhou.
This is what Computer Scientists look like.

Thank you /Sci/entists for reading my post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15119423
In the OP image, Tohru is pointing to a board where she drew a 2x2 Maid Symbol getting counted. It counts from 0 to 15 and is equivalent to hexadecimal.

Imagine you used Kurumi MaidCard on a text. Just for argument, let's say your text ended up using 8 by 8 Maid Symbols. So what happened is the text got read and a Maid-LZW dictionary got built out of 8 by 8 Maid Symbols which maps to Strings. So now you have a list of 8 by 8 Maid Symbols representing your data. At this point Kurumi MaidCard would draw it in a square (unless you told it to do something else). I propose instead to construct a new dictionary of 4 by 4 Maid Symbols. So to make a dictionary, we need all the start Symbols. We can get all the possible 4 by 4 start Maid Symbols by counting from

0000
0000
0000
0000

To

1111
1111
1111
1111

Then you can apply LZW again, this time mapping say 8 by 4 Maid Symbols to sequences of 4 by 4 ones. If you can find repeating sequences of 4 by 4 Maid Symbols, you should be able to compress again the same way you compressed from string to 8 by 8 Maid Symbols.

Using this process, it might be able to compress more. I will explore that idea more if my projects outgrow MaidCard's current abilities of distributing code. I am going to try to get other projects into a minimally viable form though, so that I can run them on the Maid Phone.

Thank you /sci/entists for reading my post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15120562
So you're trying to apply LZW to something that has been compressed by LZW already. As a general rule, successive applications of the same lossless compression algorithm won't give you more compression, since the first pass has already pushed the entropy of the message close to its limits. You'll just make a new encoding of the same information with approximately the same (or even larger, due to overhead) size.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Can you imagine a universe where no matter which direction you go, you'll eventually return back to the same place you started? Imagine if you lived in a universe like that that was quite small. If you were the only thing in the universe, no matter which way you looked you would just see yourself. It would look like the back of your head was always in front of you, and your head and body were stretched around the universe as if a lazy programmer turned your character models texture inside out then applied it to the skybox.

That's what's meant by a "closed universe". If we really live in one, the distance that you'd have to go to get back to where you started is much larger than the distance light has even been able to travel so far, so it doesn't look trippy like that.

It's a bit easier to picture if you imagine an analogy where the universe is just a two dimensional surface. Imagine living in a two-dimensional universe: you would be totally flat, your field of vision would just be a line, and you would only able to move forward and back, left and right. Now imagine that in fact your 2d space is actually the surface of a big 3d sphere. Everything in your universe would be confined to this sphere surface, even light rays. If the sphere was small enough, and you were alone in the universe, whichever way you looked you would just see light coming from your own body and wrapping around the whole sphere to get back to you.

It's tempting to think: "if curvature can be thought of as the space we experience being treated as the surface of a higher dimensional object, then surely our universe must be embedded in some higher dimensional space." But that's not necessarily true: there's no reason why the simple fact that space can be curved means that there's some additional space that it's curving into. It can just be curved in and of itself. If you were to embed it in four dimensions, however, a positively curved 3d space would look like the surface of a 4d sphere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15122383
If our universe is " flat ", that's kind of like the 2D universe just being an infinite sheet, where you can go in any direction as far as you want. We know that on the small scale (the scale where you deal with individual stars and galaxies) the universe is curved and warped by massive objects, but in the context of the whole universe " flat " just talks about what space is doing on the largest scale.

A negatively curved, open universe is harder to imagine through analogy to a 2D sheet, but it's just as different as the closed universe. See, regardless of what the universe is doing in its entirety - whether it eventually curls back on itself or goes on forever - we can still distinguish between various kinds of curvature in the small part of the universe that we can see. Angles add up differently. In a flat universe, if I go south a thousand miles, then east a thousand miles, then north a thousand miles, I end up a thousand miles east from where I started. But on a sphere like the Earth, which is positively curved, I can go a thousand miles south then a thousand miles east then a thousand miles north and end up only 900 mi east from my starting location, because the curvature of the Earth bends the south and the North leg of my journey towards each other. Another way of saying this is that in a closed universe, parallel lines eventually meet.

Being in an open universe is like living in a place where you can go south a thousand miles, east a thousand miles, then north a thousand miles and end up 1100 mi east from your starting location.. in that universe, straight lines that start out parallel will diverge if you follow them far enough.

>>15113027
It cannot explicitly said to be a number like a rational number or irrational "number." However, it exists as a matrix [math] i = \begin{pmatrx} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} [/math]. At the same time by defining [math] \hat{1} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} [/math] you can define the complex number system unique through matrix addition and multiplication and prove that it's a field. As a short hand, we can associate [math] z = x \hat{1} y i = x + iy[/math] as a shorthand and operate that way. Complex number are just a special case of matrix algebra. In here [math] i [/math] is a number in the sense that it's part of a field.

posts.name: Strange Love
posts.com:
>>15119601

>Oh? Why couldn't you just simulate it?

Ofc you "could" but the computational power for a proper simulation would be quite excessive.

>It is a bit more complex than a single gate.

That is highly generalized. The self-assembling equilibria of the cytoskeleton (which control neurotransmitter and - receptor trafficking inside the cell and thus modulate synapse sensitivity to many different stimuli) alone are very complex. Not even touching pathway crosstalk in the synapse itself, feedback with gene expression patterns, interactions with the surrounding glia cells ... many of them likely factors for the ability to "learn" and adapt within the overal neuronal architecture. Ofc you could break this down to a complex interlinked set of signal thresholds but that is far from a straightforward task ... unless you simply wanna simulate a "snapshot" of a hypothetical neuronal network.

>Why is this so different? And why couldn't we simulate it?

Could we "feasibly" for something with the same degree of complexity as a human brain? That is the question. Once proposed simply treating each neurostack as a "black box" with a random number function controlling synapse signaling thresholds ... a random function which can modify itself to be precise. Ofc, this would be a bit of a monkeys with typewriters approach but it could just hit the sweet spot by incremental improvement.

>>15119882

>i.e. doesn't necessarily mean the "lights are on" inside the brain simulation

Bingo. But emphasis would here likely be on the word "simulate". One could likely simulate a current steady state of a wetware, the synaptic connections, the activation thresholds of each neuron, perhaps even sensory input ... but that might in the end just simulate what amounts to a piece of "dead" brain matter. Talking purely biological this alone does not faithfully simulate what a brain does, every single signaling event at a synapse triggers a cascade of protein shuttling, cytoskeletal rearrangement, changes in gene expression pattern, etc ... as said previously, every single neuron is a very complex microprocessor of its own. Talking a bit beyond biology, the consciousness isn't really the physical structure this process is running on (the arrangement of neurons) but the continuously changing and adapting pattern of both electrical signaling events and rearrangements of the very internal structure (the complex interlinked semi-stable equilibria of chemical signaling events) of each and every neuron involved. Yes, especially the latter effect might be comparably miniscule overall but then it could juuust be more-than-the-sum-of-its-parts element we miss (or do not simulate faithfully enough).

Acamprosate is by far the best drug for recovering alcoholics it blocks GABA B1 receptors which enhances hippocampal neurogenesis, upregulates tyrosine hydroxylase, boosts endorphin and dopamine release and is believed to indirectly activate GABA A receptors. It restores cognitive impairment after heavy drinking, boosts endogenous taurine production and protects the brain from alcohol withdrawal glutamate surges and other sources of neurotoxicity

Prazosin (A1 blocker) used for PTSD nightmares upregulates dopamine synthesis and boosts memory in Alzheimer's, it may also reduce respiratory distress during COVID and a2c adrenergic antagonists boost PFC cortex dopamine and restore cognition in aged rodents. Brexpiprazole does all these things without raising prolactin it is the superior antipsychotic.

Fluvoxamine's potent sigma 1 agonism has antiamnesic effects significant enough to reverse scopolamine and PCP induced hyperactivity and memory impairment, it synergises with my brexpiprazole's 5ht1a agonism to promote neurogenesis.

I use vape nicotine and cannabis which both upregulate tyrosine hydroxylase and i occasionally drink ethanol, a cholinergic postive modulator


Don't forget your multivitamins kiddies

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15095742
This is not always the case. Sometimes it's the other way around actually, for example patients who are found unconscious after suffering trauma are always treated as if they had cervical spine injury.
When this is the case it's usually because benign conditions are also the most common ones so it makes sense to consider them first. The general rule in diagnosis is to consider the most common conditions rather than the most benign ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15106126
Do you get to work with cadavers? If so, don't get too deep into the intricacies of the anatomy itself and focus more on getting a good grasp for the spacial anatomy of the heart and the mediastinum, you won't get another chance to work with the anatomy as thoroughly as you do in cadaver studies, and the better you understand it, the easier it will be for you to visualize the anatomy once you're working with living patients. I've done a lot of cadaver work in medschool and while most of the specific anatomy got lost again over time, the feeling for spacial relations within the body didn't, it's pretty usefull, especially with the continued push for minimaly invasive surgery and the at times akward access pathways you'll have to deal with. As for the specific anatomy, don't sweat it too much, you'll forget most of it while studying for other subjects you don't care for anyways, just focus on getting through medschool and into residency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15110990
I would take a DCABCD approach
I would first take a split second to assess the possible dangers - it is likely that this alien ichor will be toxic to me in some form or other - be it through direct acute properties like being filled with caustic material, or longer term things like using methylmercury as part of its Hb equivalent. Either way, it seems likely that deciding not to treat it, despite the unknown dangers, is likely to cause repercussions from other members of its species. If I don't combust into flame or something upon touching it, I will proceed to C - catastrophic haemorrhage.
We can deduce some physiology of the alien from its appearance - if it is 4 limbed with a torso, it probably has vital organs in the torso, and thus tourniquets are probably useful, if the bleeding is from a limb. The nature of the bleeding - its pressure, the waveform of it - will be helpful to deduce if it has something similar to a heart
Massive exsanguating haemorrhage will be controlled through pressure and tourniquets.
The airway is tricky, because intubating is absolutely contraindicated - we have no idea its anatomy. A quick inspection of the face and mouth, with suctioning of any blood and secretions, followed by sniffing the morning air position, is the best we could do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15116837
When it comes to breathing, we have no idea the gas mixture it requires, nor the tidal volumes, nor the frequency- or even if it breathes. It may breathe in one orifice and out another, in a continuous flow, as opposed to the in/out cycle we have. Watching for rise and fall of the chest in the first instance may give some clue here, which might guide my bag mask ventilation. In terms of oxygenation, it's shit out of luck if it needs chlorine or fluorine to breathe, so due to a lack of harm if it does breathe these (as it will likely asphyxiate before stores of these can be obtained), I would crank the fio2 in my mask to 100%. Anatomy would again be our worst enemy, and if the alien has bizarre facial anatomy, we will never get a good seal. We may resort to high-flow nasal prongs in the first instance, if, say, they had a face like a sangheili.

Now we are back to circulation. A crude assessment of its perfusion should be performed - distal "capillary" refill seems reasonable. We should attempt to gain access to the aliens vasculature - going in blind, however, would be a fools errand. We need thr US, as this will help establish if a) they have a classical art/vein anatomy and b) where these are. I want a line in every sonographically different vessel we can find, and I want the following blood tests on each - an istat gas and electrolytes, formal electrolytes, microscopy, mass spectrometry and a rotem. These should be self explanatory - and will guide fluid replacement. Whatever the electrolyte mix of the alienblood we will try to match with whatever I have in stock, and start pouring that into it.
While I have the us, it seems not unreasonable to look into its torso and abdomen in an equivalent to a FAST scan- although note that it may not have an organised vasculature system and free fluid should not automatically make us think of internal bleeding.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15116871
Disability will be challenging to assess, as we do not speak each other's language. At baseline, it may appear calm or demented to us, or anything in between. On the off chance that it decided to learn our language on the multi light year trip it took before coming here, I would attempt to communicate with it, and tell our progress and what it needs from us.
Once this primary survey is complete, I would again run through it and repeat every time anything appeared to change.
It's vital signs, of pulse rate, blood pressure, resp rate and spo2 (the last being very unlikely to be able to be read from Point of care monitoring) may provide a guide on whether we are winning or losing.

I realise I forgot to mention earlier, that all our pharmacology is unlikely to help and likely to he acutely toxic to it, and so vasopressors, coagulants and other agents are not helpful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15116908
After optimising abcd, it's time to run it through the scanner. A CT non-con sounds like the least dangerous and most useful to perform. If I had concerns with regards to internal bleeding, I might have to bite the bullet and use iodine contrast, and hope it isn't like arsenic to the alien. Endovascular occlusion may be am option if there is contrast leak (bleeding) in somewhere that it doesn't appear to be physiological for it - asymmetric, appearing uncontrolled, creating fluid pockets where there weren't any initially.

From this scan, we have our first look at its internals - what does it use to exchange gas, what does it do to pump blood. The anatomy will perhaps give clues on how to optimise things, such as decreasing tidal volumes or changing which vessel we put fluid through. We may even get enoigh information for a stab at intubating it - using fibre optic and appropriate cuff sizes

Note the dangers of MRI - what if it had a few micrograms of antimatter suspended in a magnetic field to power internal implants? The mri disturbing that would kill everyone. Even after a CT to exude macroscopic implants, I wouldn't trust it.

Hopefully we eventually get collateral, specifically information about its physiology, as well as specialised pharmacology agents for it, otherwise my only treatment options is that homecooked fluid I discussed earlier, pressure for bleeding and supportive care.

Ampere conducted a fascinating experiment (picrel) in which he demonstrated a property of mercury (and magnetism) in which longitudinal forces are generated, which aren't predicted by Maxwell's equations (but are predicted by Ampere's original electrodynamics, which quantified the force between any two current elements).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It means how far light goes in one year.
Light always goes the same speed, so a light year is the distance traveled by light after one year.

It's a good unit of measurement for distances because light is the fastest possible speed and it puts distances into perspective.

Our galaxy is several light years wide. Meaning it would take us years to leave the galaxy if we could even go the speed of light. A light minute is also a unit of distance. The distance from earth to the sun is about five light minutes. That's how long it takes sunlight to arrive on the Earth from the sun.

Power systems was anout analysis of bus systems that were in series and/or parallel and either balanced or unbalanced 3 phase.

We have prep chambers and load locks so we can transfer in and out samples without having to vent (we also have a UHV chamber on wheels that allows us to transfer from system to system all in UHV), bur if we have to make repairs we have to vent. For most of our systems, we can go years without venting, with the exception of our MBE systems, which have to be vented periodically to refill the sources (we're not fancy enough to be able to valve off our source ports)


Our MBE systems are particularly annoying to vent, since we have to degas our source, which takes about another week to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i was literally talking to my mom about this the other day.
by using an electric heater, you're taking fuel (maybe even natural gas) and it's being burned in a power plant to boil water, and that water spins a turbine to make electricity. then that electricity travels down the wires to your house, where you turn it into heat again to cook your food.

or, you just burn natural gas on site to cook your food.

if the choice is between burning natural gas at your house to heat food, or using electricity made from burning natural gas to heat your food (and chances are it is from natural gas, because about 40% of the electricity in the US is from natural gas) it is absolutely more efficient to use a natural gas stove. an electrical one wastes more gas per unit heat, because you're converting the gas into heat, then into electricity, then back into heat, and losing power every step of the way.

it would be one thing if only a small part of our power generation was natural gas, but it's not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117368
you would think that, but in reality it's basically the same

10-30% of the gas will leak out on the way from well to stove because fittings, welds, etc. aren't perfect, are decades old and generally not maintained unless it gets bad enough to cause alarm
gas burner is 90% efficient at converting chemical to thermal energy
but then 50% of the thermal energy will go around the pot and out the chimney (so to speak)
overall ~40-30%

combined cycles coal plants can reach 60% efficiency, old and dirty ones can be as low a 30% efficient to thermal and thermal to electricity (let's ignore nuclear, hydro and solar for now)
distribution by wires is about 90% efficient
induction is like 90% efficient because you're heating the pot and stuff in it (losses in inductor are not significant)
overall ~45-25%

I tried to do medical research and spent a year on a project and it turned me off it forever.

It's all some insular world of funding chasing (50% of your time). The funding usually comes from government in some token "we think it would be good to fund science in x area" system. You lose staff whenever you don't get consistent funding for them so you're always just chasing the next grant.

Best way of getting the good departmental output rankings you need to won funding is to always go for safe options to keep mindlessly churning out 'good quality' studies where the study quality is the aim, not whatever is being tested. Usually you just play it safe and do the smallest variation of other successfully published studies ensuring it will be published and no-one will ever read it.

Adding to this is that most involved care for nothing more than increasing their citations. It's not uncommon to see pajeet doctors with thousands of citations on studies theyve never done anything on other than irresponsibility shunted a patient to the team. They then get more weight and reputation and they continue doing it more.

Basically it's devolved into a weird useless ecosystem populated by low IQ managers and dishonest self promoters. If you went in trying to earnestly work to advance science you'd get no support then no funding.

Back in ye olde timely days a scientist must've appeared like the holder of all truths. It didn't take much for the rare individuals who had both extraordinary natural mental gifts and extensive schooling to seem like they knew more than a layman about every subject imaginable. From anatomy, biology and geology to history, engineering, politics and philosophy. To a working class man they might hold a status not unlike sage's and oracle's of antiquity.

Louis pasteurs' various experiments are low tech and easily replicable. Petri dish procedures are simple and easy to perform if you want to select and examine specific individual microbial strains (mind you, only visual distinction is possible without additional and moderately priced equipment).

If you want to confirm or research transmission of pathogens on your own in Vivo experiments are necessary. Luckily you won't need to resort to animal experiments. You can use root vegetables to confirm transmission of mold transmission. If you feel up to it you can use insects to illustrate bacterial transmission. Just capture a few live flies, have them crawl around inside a Petri dish with a culture, then transfer them to a sterile growth plate and let them walk around for a few minutes and then let the growth medium cultivate a day or two.

These experiments, at the very least, would show you personally that germ theory is a good hypothesis. If you're serious in your critical approach, you can explore further experiments that require slightly more time and effort?
How's that sound? Could be worth the time to perform if you're truly skeptical right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
[math]

\delta \, \epsilon \left ( 0,1 \right ) \\
\displaystyle
\prod_{k=0}^{n} \left ( 1 + \delta ^{2^{k}} \right )
= (1+ \delta)(1+ \delta ^{2})(1+ \delta ^{4}) \cdots (1+ \delta ^{2^{n-1}})(1+ \delta ^{2^{n}}) \\
(1- \delta) \prod_{k=0}^{n} \left ( 1+ \delta ^{2^{k}} \right )
= (1- \delta)(1+ \delta)(1+ \delta ^{2})(1+ \delta ^{4}) \cdots (1+ \delta ^{2^{n-1}})(1+ \delta ^{2^{n}}) \\
= (1- \delta ^{2})(1+ \delta ^{2})(1+ \delta ^{4}) \cdots (1+ \delta ^{2^{n-1}})(1+ \delta ^{2^{n}}) \\
= (1- \delta ^{4})(1+ \delta ^{4}) \cdots (1+ \delta ^{2^{n-1}})(1+ \delta ^{2^{n}})
= (1- \delta ^{2^{n}})(1+ \delta ^{2^{n}}) = 1- \delta ^{2^{n+1}} \\
\\
\boxed{(\delta ^{2^n})^2 = \delta ^{2 \cdot 2^n}=\delta^{2^{n+1}}}
\\
\displaystyle
\prod_{k=0}^{n} \left ( 1+ \delta ^{2^{k}} \right )
= \dfrac{1- \delta^{2^{n+1}}}{1- \delta} \\
\displaystyle
\lim_{n \to \infty} \prod_{k=0}^{n} \left (1+ \delta ^{2^{k}} \right )
= \lim_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{1- \delta^{2^{n+1}}}{1- \delta} = \dfrac{1}{1- \delta}
[/math]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15122321
Little balls do go down the copper. They go very slowly, and as they move they create a big field all around the wire, with the wire in the center.

This works whether you push them all in the same direction all the time, or even if you just jiggle them back and forth really fast.

The balls can go down the wire because all the metal atoms basically share their outer orbitals with each other. That means that there's basically nothing stopping an electron on one atom from moving to an adjoining atom, as long as another electron comes from behind to replace it. The metal atoms nuclei are all positively charged, held together in a lattice by the structure of the electrons in the inner orbitals, and the electrons in the outer orbitals are like a negatively charged fluid, soaking through the lattice to make it neutrally charged everywhere.

I'd suggest making some small independent projects to prove that you can program outside of coursework.
To ease into it, maybe start by making a project that's similar to some homework you've done- but from scratch without referring to your prior work.
As for webdev, there are certainly many more web roles out there than embedded ones, so if you were to pick up some Javascript and make a todo list website, that might help.
Webdev moves fast (rapidly changing standards, lots of trendy framework-of-the-month usage, etc) and it can be a headache to keep up with, but it's also inherently simpler than many of the concepts you've already learned. Anyone who can program a microcontroller can definitely learn React easily enough, and good recruiters will know this.
>data management
Basic SQL would be worthwhile.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15119246
software engineering is not CS, and it's the big lie from schools that CS degrees are related to software development. It's a field of work (which is sometimes engineering, depending on the nature of what you're doing - though at that point, a CS degree is usually preferable!) that ranges from everything like writing basic scripts and sql queries to making the OS for the mars rover. But nobody trusts newbies with the latter. You get there after years of experience in designing, implementing, and maintaining complicated systems.

The big thing is that nobody, and I mean NOBODY, knows how to engineer software without being taught by professionals in the field. This includes CS majors. So focus on the fundamentals you need to pass a whiteboard interview (codeforces/leetcode to grind out some problems, basic data structures + comp arch, etc..), and they'll teach you once you pass the interview.

You can get *a* software engineering job for sure, but you might not get an interesting one, which is my disclaimer. Interesting software engineering jobs are rare and worth their weight in gold.

There are many good textbooks because there's a lot of math that applies to ML. But I really like Mohri's Foundations of ML personally. It's free on his website:
https://cs.nyu.edu/~mohri/mlbook/

Other books like PRML are also great

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15119259
Also
>a friend recommended machine learning as a lucrative field.
kiiinda. ML is an insanely competitive field that values experimental progress over science and explainability. There is a constant race to develop novel, competitive techniques, which pushes a lot of research dollars. On the other hand, actually researching ML is an afterthought. People want to engineer systems that converge to (reasonable) answers faster and with fewer resources while running. They're content to know only as much as will tell them certain techniques are fundamentally limited, and they will wait decades before funding the research that goes into maturing these techniques into a proper theory / field.

You will make pennies in ML unless you're among the best. You'll likely lose a lot of sleep and free time if you're in it for the money. If you want to make money while being adjacent to computer science, do something like software engineering or systems CS. The former has a lot of jobs that pay handsomely compared to the work needed, and the latter has incredibly stable funding and actual, real world, impactful results, but you don't have to compromise scientific and engineering quality to stay relevant.

>>15121393
>you are literally giving up money if you go for a phd in ML. i expect a phd to completely destroyed my earnings potential.
I didn't disagree with you? The issue is that the highest earning PhD ML researchers destroy everyone's earnings potential, but there are literally < 100 of them. It's not a market where you can bank on the availability of such positions.
>i mean is it pennies? i'm assuming you'll make 50-150k as an ML researcher instead of 200-400k as a SWE. certainly lower, but not pennies
Pennies relative to the amount of work you have to do, that is to say, your amortized pay per hour is much lower, and you're typically doing much more high intensity activities to fight for that position.

My take is that doing any sort of science and engineering research is intentionally trading off earnings potential to work on high impact and interesting problems. It's not that it's a bad proposition entirely, but that '
1) you have to be sure that you're the type of person who cares more working harder on more interesting problems, but that getting it done is satisfying and fulfilling
2) despite the above, you're still making a reasonable amount of money doing it

My point is that people in other areas of CS also work hard, but they don't have to slave away marginal gains in their work to stay remotely competitive week to week. ML is not only hard - it's oversaturated, and the only meaningful measure of success for MANY labs is architecting small gains in DL techniques until you burnout. From my perspective, working on ML theory is a more interesting yet much less popular position to be in because you get to pre empt large changes and trends, but you trade off relevance for quite a long time. But at this point, I think the better play would have been to be a CS theorist rather than an ML-only guy.

By the nested interval definition of infinite decimals, for any natural number n we have
[math]0.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm n~digits} \le 0.999... \le 1.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm n~digits}[/math]
meaning [math]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^n} \le 0.999... \le 1[/math].
Assume to the contrary that [math]0.999... <> 1[/math].
We can only have [math]0.999... < 1[/math], so [math]1 - 0.999... > 0[/math].
Let N be a natural number greater than [math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{1 - 0.999...}[/math]; then [math]\displaystyle 1 - 0.999... > \frac{1}{N}[/math] and [math]\displaystyle 0.999... < 1 - \frac{1}{N}[/math].
It follows that
[math]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^N} < 1 - \frac{1}{N}[/math]
[math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{10^N} > \frac{1}{N}[/math]
[math]10^N < N[/math]
which is not true for any natural number.
Therefore 0.999... = 1.

By the nested interval definition of infinite decimals, for any natural number n we have
[math]0.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm n~digits} \le 0.999... \le 1.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm n~digits}[/math].
Given any natural number m, we can substitute n = m + 1 into the above, obtaining
[math]0.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm m+1~digits} \le 0.999... \le 1.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm m+1~digits}[/math]
and then multiplying both sides of each inequality by 10 to get
[math]9.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm m~digits} \le 10 \cdot 0.999... \le 10.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm m~digits}[/math].
This is exactly the definition of 9.999... . (We can show that 9.999... represents a unique real number by a proof similar to >>15118709)
Therefore 10 * 0.999... = 9.999... .

[math] \forall n \in \mathbb{N} : (\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k}) + \frac{1}{10^n} = 1 [/math]
What is true for every element is also true for the limit.
Therefore [math] \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} (\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k}) + \frac{1}{10^n} =_{(equals)} 1 [/math]

When dealing with 0.999... what is studied isn't equality but convergence, the equal symbol is the same but the meaning is not the same.

[math] \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} (\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k}) =_{(tends\ towards)} 1 [/math]

However
[math] \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k} < \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k} + \frac{1}{10^n} [/math] as in straight up inferior.

>>15120339
Anon, take as in >>15118709 that [math]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^n} \le 0.999... \le 1[/math] for any natural number n.
Then assume, as assumed in that post, that [math]0.999... < 1[/math]
Then, what does that mean?
We can do the following manipulation:
[eqn]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^n} \le 0.999...[/eqn]
[eqn]\displaystyle \frac{1}{10^n} -1 \ge -0.999...[/eqn]
[eqn]\displaystyle \frac{1}{10^n}\ge 1-0.999...[/eqn]
[eqn]\displaystyle 10^n\le \frac{1}{1-0.999...}[/eqn]
Now, next the next step done in the post was to let there be a N greater than [math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{1 - 0.999...}[/math]
BUT. What does that mean? It means that since [math]\displaystyle 10^n\le \frac{1}{1-0.999...}[/math] for any natural number n, he is letting there be a natural number N greater than [math]\displaystyle 10^n[/math] including for N itself, since it is a natural number.
In other words he is letting there be a N such that [math]\displaystyle N > 10^N[/math]
He is assuming that.
But now, look at the end of his proof in >>15118709
Look at the very thing he claimed to be a contradiction. He claimed [math]10^N < N[/math] was a contradiction, the very thing he assumed to be true for N, the very thing he LET be true for N.
It wasn't a proof by contradiction at all, all he did was derive what he already assumed to be true of his own volition.

We assume as an axiom of real numbers that any real number has a natural number larger than it. This includes [math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{1 - 0.999...}[/math] if such a number exists. If you want to invent your own system of numbers in which this axiom does not hold, you are free to do so, and many such systems already exist. But if whether 0.999... = 1 is a question about real numbers, we will assume the axioms of real numbers when answering it.

This is the thing a lot of people seem to be discounting. A manned space program needs a station because there's nothing useful for a crew of cosmonauts to do on a free-flying Soyuz or Orel. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15120139
Hot air balloons do act as sails, the envelope presents a large cross section and they will go up and down looking for a wind current in the direction they wish to travel.

It gets more interesting with powered airships, as they still act as a sail. But their shape means they typically want to weathervane into the wind. This diminishes your control when going with the wind, but gives you a boost in ground speed. Against the wind you can be slowed to a crawl or worse. Side on to the wind you will have to expend some of your thrust to maintain course to prevent drifting with the wind.

Rockets also experience these forces, however the wind velocity is going to be such a small component of the air velocity during flight you can mostly ignore it. Though it does matter if you have a consistent wind on accent as that could impact your orbit. I would also imagine that wind matters more when. Propulsively landing, as you are much slower and can be pushed off target.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15122436
>non-reusable
Yes

>very complicated
Not really. High altitude weather balloons are a pretty well understood technology at this point. The engines are all pressure fed and the largest are only 15 kN designs, so the propulsion is on the easier side of things. Launching from up in the stratosphere means you don't need to worry about having surface and vacuum optimized engines. It's a clever way to do an air launched rocket that doesn't risk human crew on a carrier aircraft or require you to spend millions designing some kind of drone launch vehicle.

Unfortunately, the last anyone seems to have heard from Zero2Infinity was a test flight back in 2017, during which they acknowledged that they were having trouble raising money and were planning to focus on their weather balloon projects since those actually brought in revenue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15119068

The purpose of Lebesgue integration isn't to integrate "practical function", because a function that is Riemann integrable is Lebesgue integrable. The purpose is to make the manipulation of sequences and theorems of convergence easier. Dominated convergence theorem is very hard to prove with Riemann paradigm and the formalization of probabilities becomes very difficult. Lebesgue integration provides a framework that sets foundation for probabilities, and advanced concept like conditionnal expectation or Wiener's measure couldn't be developped without it.

Lebesgue's theory is also the root of dynamic systems' study.

I hope I was clear enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15120136
There's more of a use to teaching students how to write proofs and encouraging them to write proofs than there is in teaching them individual proofs. By writing proofs, students become sure that what they are learning is not only true, but that they are also capable of understanding why certain statements are true.

>>15120145
But if a proof is the gold standard, why not learn more of them? Presumably it helps you think rigorously too. Does it matter if the two proofs are for the same or different statements? Does one lead to more understanding than the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15120136
>Is there any use in teaching him how it was proved?
1) you teach the student how to approach proofwriting in general
2) you teach them an approach to starting (almost always the hardest thing to learn when doing rigorous mathematics). in this case, it's usually proof by contradiction
3) you teach them a technique to approach a general class of similar problems. in this case, the astute student might think, "hm, I guess a decent amount of these number problems can be tackled by looking at prime factorizations."

If you keep differentiating a function it goes to zero.

Make the curve on the Cartesian plot a bunch of |||||||| instead of OOOOOO

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15119168
From a pure mathematics point of view, Euler's number seems to pretty much pop up anytime compound and/or continuous change is involved. Why is somewhat unanswerable, it just is there. Why is pi 3.14...? Why that particular set of digits? It's just a fact of life, like the speed of light.

From an applied math point of view, it's important to realize that physics/economics and so on works just as models. Electromagnetic fields doesn't literally propagate as vectors, and economic trends or any other wave-phenomena don't literally boil down to a sin/cos graphs. Sin notation is just useful to model the situation, so we use it with perhaps some modifications to actually fit our world. Therefore, it is unfair to say Sin is inherently hardbaked into physics or earthquake activity or whatever. Similarly, Euler's number is used a lot just because it has useful properties for modeling exponential functions (it is it's own derivative etc. etc.). You could use anything else, it would just be less than ideal.

Wood contains volatile organic compounds called terpenes. Turpentine is a naturally occurring solvent that was used as paint thinner prior to the invention of synthetic petrochemical solvents. Extracting turpentine from wood was once a major industry. Rocket stoves function by evaporating volatile organic compounds out of wood and then burning them in a separate chamber. On a side note, the volatile organic compounds inside wood are what give whisky its distinct flavor.
